factoid: Prince Vasíli said, "Tomorrow we are off at last."
Prince Vasíli closed his eyes and was fingering Pierre's elbow.
Prince Vasíli spoke as if something had long been agreed upon and could not now be altered.
Prince Vasíli said, "We start tomorrow and I am giving you a place in my carriage."
Prince Vasíli said, "I am very glad."
Prince Vasíli said, "All our important business here is now settled."
Prince Vasíli said, "I ought to have been off long ago."
Prince Vasíli said, "Here is something I have received from the chancellor."
Prince Vasíli said, "I asked him for you."
Prince Vasíli said, "You have been entered in the diplomatic corps."
Prince Vasíli said, "You have been made a Gentleman of the Bedchamber."
Prince Vasíli said, "The diplomatic career now lies open before you."
Pierre had been considering his career for a long time.
Pierre wished to make some suggestion.
Prince Vasíli interrupted Pierre in a special deep cooing tone.
Prince Vasíli's interruption precluded the possibility of interrupting Pierre's speech.
Prince Vasíli used this special deep cooing tone in extreme cases when special persuasion was needed.
Prince Vasíli said, "I did this for my own sake to satisfy my conscience."
Prince Vasíli said, "There is nothing to thank me for."
Prince Vasíli said, "No one has ever complained yet of being too much loved."
Prince Vasíli said, "Besides, you are free."
Prince Vasíli said, "You could throw it up tomorrow."
Prince Vasíli said, "You will see everything for yourself when you get to Petersburg."
Prince Vasíli said, "It is high time for you to get away from these terrible recollections."
Prince Vasíli sighed.
Prince Vasíli said, "Yes, yes, my boy."
Prince Vasíli said, "My valet can go in your carriage."
Prince Vasíli said, "I was nearly forgetting."
Prince Vasíli said, "Your father and I had some accounts to settle."
Prince Vasíli said, "I have received what was due from the Ryazán estate."
Prince Vasíli said, "I will keep it."
Prince Vasíli said, "You won't require it."
Prince Vasíli said, "We'll go into the accounts later."
Prince Vasíli meant that what was due from the Ryazán estate was several thousand rubles quitrent received from Pierre's peasants, which Prince Vasíli had retained for himself.
In Petersburg, Pierre found the same atmosphere of gentleness and affection as in Moscow.
Pierre could not refuse the post that Prince Vasíli had procured for him.
Pierre could not refuse the rank that Prince Vasíli had procured for him.
Acquaintances, invitations, and social occupations were numerous in Petersburg.
Pierre felt a sense of bewilderment, bustle, and continual expectation of some good.
The expectation of some good was always in front of Pierre but never attained.
Many of Pierre's former bachelor acquaintances were no longer in Petersburg.
The Guards had gone to the front.
Dólokhov had been reduced to the ranks.
Anatole was in the army somewhere in the provinces.
Prince Andrew was abroad.
Pierre did not have the opportunity to spend his nights as he used to.
Pierre did not have the opportunity to open his mind by intimate talks with a friend older than himself whom he respected.
Pierre's whole time was taken up with dinners and balls.
Pierre's whole time was spent chiefly at Prince Vasíli's house.
Pierre spent time in the company of Prince Vasíli's wife, who is a stout princess.
Pierre spent time in the company of Prince Vasíli's daughter Hélène, who is beautiful.
Anna Pávlovna Schérer showed Pierre the change of attitude toward him that had taken place in society.
In Anna Pávlovna's presence, Pierre had always felt that what he was saying was out of place, tactless, and unsuitable.
In Anna Pávlovna's presence, remarks that seemed clever to Pierre became foolish as soon as he uttered them.
Hippolyte's stupidest remarks came out clever and apt.
Now everything Pierre said was charming.
Even if Anna Pávlovna did not say so, Pierre could see that she wished to.
Pierre could see that Anna Pávlovna only refrained out of regard for his modesty.
In the beginning of the winter of 1805-6, Pierre received one of Anna Pávlovna's usual pink notes with an invitation.
The invitation added the sentence, "You will find the beautiful Hélène here, whom it is always delightful to see."
When Pierre read that sentence, Pierre felt for the first time that some link which other people recognized had grown up between himself and Hélène.
That thought alarmed Pierre, as if some obligation was being imposed on him which he could not fulfill.
That thought pleased Pierre as an entertaining supposition.
